title: Higher Tariffs Take Effect, New 100% Levy on Chips; BOE Set to Cut
description:
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe is your essential morning viewing to stay ahead. Live from London, we set the agenda for your day, catching you up with overnight markets news from the US and Asia. And we'll tell you what matters for investors in Europe, giving you insight before trading begins.

On today's show, higher US tariffs come into effect, including 39% on Switzerland after the Swiss President left Washington empty-handed. Donald Trump also announces 100% tariffs on semiconductor imports, but companies including Apple will be exempt if they begin moving production back to the US. Relief over those exemptions sees markets rally, helped by TSMC and Samsung.

Also on the programme, the Bank of England set to cut rates to their lowest in two years as policymakers try to balance a slowing economy with sticky inflation.

Today's guest: Nina Skero, Centre for Economics & Business Research, CEO (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: The US President has implemented higher tariffs on U.S. products, including those from Apple, while the World Bank of England (BOE) is set to cut these as a result of the higher tariffs. The President's announcement comes as companies like Apple are being targeted with 100% LEVIES on Chips, while companies in the U.K. like Amazon are being singled out for their exclusion. Meanwhile, four major companies have dropped their Q3 earnings, with companies like Allianz reporting a significant decrease in Q3 revenues and an operating profit of 44.5 BILLION EUROS. The Bank of Europe is also set to reduce its Rates as a precautionary measure due to the slow economy. The European Union has been sending out a warning to the public about potential economic instability.
shortSummary: The Trump administration's tariffs and new 100% Levy on chips are impacting global trade, causing significant losses for companies like Apple, while the Bank of England may cut interest rates.
argos_summary: U.S. tariffs, including a 100% chip levy and a 39% Swiss import duty, took effect at midnight, lifting the U.S. 10‑year yield by 2‑4 bp and boosting semiconductor stocks. The Bank of England’s 25‑bp rate cut, announced the same day, supported equity markets and tightened the U.S. dollar index, while the tariff hike is expected to pressure global trade flows, especially India’s 50% duty.
